prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The Panel does not normally permit the taxation of costs. Nor does it allow the recovery of attorneys' fees. Despite the absence of any provision for taxation of costs or the award of fees under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407, it is possible that the Panel would make such an award in certain circumstances.

It is difficult to imagine how the Panel could permit a party to tax costs. Costs are normally assessed at the conclusion of proceedings, and proceedings do not conclude before the Panel. They may be terminated in the transferee court or may be remanded to the transferor court for termination; the Panel does not enter dispositive orders nor does it decide questions going to the merits of the litigation. Presumably, costs should not be taxed by the Panel.[1] It is possible that Panel proceedings may be related to activities that do create taxable costs under the statutes. Proceedings before the Panel, and before the transferor court before transfer is ordered, are to be treated by the transferee court the same as if they had been conducted before that court. Thus, taxable items of expense related to the Panel proceedings may be taxable upon disposition in either the transferee court or transferor court.[2]

Attorneys' fees probably may be awarded by the Panel. In one case the Panel decided not to award fees against a moving party, for the reason that it determined that the motion for transfer under the statute was not frivolous.[3] The Panel did not imply in that decision that it would entertain a motion to award fees; but the decision offers some support for that conclusion. The Panel did not decide it could not award fees, it decided merely that it would not under the facts of the case.

Panel pleadings are signed in accordance with Rule 11 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Fed. R. Civ. P. 11 provides a substantial basis for the imposition of sanctions against an attorney filing a frivolous pleading or related document. Fed. R. Civ. P. 7 incorporates the same standard for all motions. The breach of these rules would permit the Panel to impose an appropriate sanction. The inherent power of the Panel would also permit the imposition of sanctions, including attorneys' fees, for misconduct before it.

The Panel has repeatedly expressed its strong reliance on comity and inter-court relations in permitting the Panel to achieve the purposes of the statute.[4] The Panel should not, and likely would not, impose sanctions except in egregious circumstances not related to proceedings in either the transferee court or transferor court.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
Taxation of costs is discussed in greater detail in David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice§ 23.02 (8th ed. 2019).

See In re Royal Typewriter Co. (Royal Bond Copier) Breach of Warranty Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 925, 926 (J.P.M.L. 1977) (award denied on facts of case); In re San Juan, Puerto Rico Air Crash Disaster, 316 F. Supp. 981 (J.P.M.L. 1970) (Panel declined to condition transfer order on payment of travel expenses of party opposing transfer).
In re Royal Typewriter Co. (Royal Bond Copier) Breach of Warranty Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 925, 926 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
The Panel's deference to other courts, particularly the transferee court, is discussed in greater detail in Chapter 9.
